text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for review of the new bad bad not
good record 3 bad bad not good is a
toronto-based jazz trio this is a third
record if you haven't figured that out
it's out on innovative leisure records
and you might remember back in 2011
these guys were making waves doing
instrumental reinterpretations of hip
hop instrumentals from artists like nas
and odd future and they were also going
a step further and covering like video
game music from the Zelda Ocarina of
Time soundtrack the production was good
the performances were tight these guys
definitely value raw energy and just
explosive
electrifying togetherness then they did
flashy solos or anything like that but
the quality of the performances and the
playing and the solos all got turned up
on the band's next full-length LP BB ng
- and on this sophomore record the band
also experimented with putting some more
original material on the LP as well as
taking out covers from James Blake and
Kanye West even My Bloody Valentine on
the final track here and lately these
guys been doing backing instrumentation
and production for other artists as well
like Earl Pharoahe Monch and lately
they've had some really awesome Flying
Lotus and tonight covers that I've been
hearing them pull out in the live
setting as well so at the moment bad bad
not good is sitting at this really
interesting crossroads of jazz and hip
hop and modern electronic music and
interpreting a lot of this stuff they're
just a really fearsome Punk spirit and
all these flavors come together on this
new record of theirs that is 100%
original material but maybe not quite as
jazz oriented as I was expecting or
hoped bass piano and drums still work as
the foundation of bad bad not good sound
but they work in a lot of other sounds
as well like sub base hits and guitar
and saxophone and what sounds like
strings this is bad bad not goods most
instrumentally lush release however
there doesn't seem to be as much of a
focus on the solos on this LP or just
jamming in general now there are some
solos on the cell
that do stand out and do sort of you
know really take the spotlight like the
upright bass solo on the song eyes
closed or the bass and drum jam on the
song kaleidoscope and there's the song
differently still which is a bit of a an
old school jazz oasis in the middle of
this LP where the trio is sounding like
a trio from the 1960s now even though
there are solos on this record that
standout in bad bad not good definitely
make room for them in the mix in the
structure of the song the band is
obviously just working with a different
formula now they've moved beyond
improving over other people's stuff that
they are recreating and are now just
creating their own original material and
because of that it seems like they're
more focused on just making a good song
that sounds very nice as opposed to
coming together with a fiery performance
of said song take the song confessions
for example which has Leyland Witte on
at playing saxophone frequent
collaborator with bad bad not good
however his playing on this track is I
don't know just a little tame little
uninvented and comparison with what I've
heard and do with the band before yes it
definitely breaks up the sequence of
these tracks by bringing a nice bright
beautifully sounding saxophone into the
mix but it's not like an explosion of a
track for me despite the very pretty and
smooth swells of sax drums pianos and
bass on a lot of the choruses of this
track and and I do love the very
hypnotic
saxophone cycles that Leyland is playing
through on the song it's just really
obvious that bad bad not good is more
worried about composition on this record
than they are improvisation and it's not
necessarily a bad thing because the
effort does show like the song
kaleidoscope which starts off with these
are Lee Chile keyboards and eventually
builds up into these saxophone melodies
these saxophone harmonies that sound
like something out of Frank Zappa's hot
rats the instrumentation on this track
is really just rich it's really grand
it's beautiful then there's the song
eyes closed which has this really dreary
you reverb so guitar playing throughout
at the band builds up to a really
climactic finish at the end it's really
in my opinion a quality nod to post rock
and then there's the song since you
asked kindly which isn't one of my
favourite tracks on here it's not really
a riveting song for me it gets a little
redundant in the mid section with these
repetitive key
our leads but it's one of the more
unexpected tracks for me on this record
because it takes kind of an instrumental
synth pop direction with the analog
production it sounds like the song was
recorded 40 years ago or something and
then there's songs on this record like
can't leave the night which is one of
the lead singles to this LP and on this
song bad bad not good essentially come
up with their own version of a banger
with these keyboard melodies that sound
like they were taken straight out of a
Flying Lotus song and these sub bass
lines that hit once the drop comes that
feel like they were pulled straight out
of tonight track and the track is fine
it's decent
I've given a multiple listen since it
was originally released on the Internet
but as I listen to in the context of
this record many times I can't say I'm
really excited with the song beyond the
concept of it it's like bad bad not good
is really trying to refine the banger
trying to refine this hard-hitting
bombastic thing and it doesn't end up
subtle enough to be seductive and yet
it's not hard-hitting enough to the
point where I flip or I just go crazier
I get this rush of energy once the drop
comes and the same kind of goes for the
song cs6 t2 which kind of shoots for the
same formula but is much more ambitious
with a more expansive song structure
tons of strings that help bring the song
to a climactic finish but here as well
bad bad not good try like hell to fit
these sub bass sounds into the song and
a logical and tasteful way but it's just
short of actually being so with this LP
overall I'm not in love with it but it's
not really like a huge disappointment
for me or anything like that I thought
it was good I think bad bad not good
still brought a lot of positive
characteristics to the table for one the
production is fantastic I think they
blend their influences creatively
there's a lot of sound play on this
record I think stylistically bad bad not
good continue to be adventurous and I
think it's really interesting that
they're incorporating just nothing but
original material on this LP and most of
its really good but on this new record
or there's I don't think bad bad not
good really puts the performance fire
into these tracks that they usually do
other people's material weirdly enough
or other older original tracks like
rotten decay for example and because of
that this record can kind of be a little
mundane sometimes
every guy on this LP feels so
methodically planned and feels so
measured that even the high points even
the the climaxes of the record just kind
of hang in the yellow but still I can
see even that being a turn-on for other
people you know this is bad bad not
goods most orchestrated LP it's also
their moodiest LP I was just hoping for
a bit more emotional and instrumental
variety on this record and just maybe
some stronger playing but that's about
it I'm feeling a decent of strong 7 on
this thing transition if you've given
this record to listen what did you think
of it did you love it hate it why what
do you think I should review next and
that said Anthony Fantan oh I'm not good
forever
